entities.name: harry
entities.description: The main protagonist of the story. He is described as stopping at the gate and staring out at the garden.

entities.name: dumbledore
entities.description: A wise and knowledgeable character who would have believed Harry's story. He is mentioned as having explained the connection between Harry's wand and Voldemort's.

entities.name: mad-eye
entities.description: A character who, like Dumbledore, Sirius, and Harry's parents, is gone where Harry can never talk to them again.

entities.name: sirius
entities.description: A character who, like Dumbledore, Mad-Eye, and Harry's parents, is gone where Harry can never talk to them again.

entities.name: voldemort
entities.description: The antagonist of the story. He has a connection with Harry's wand.

entities.name: harry's parents
entities.description: Harry's parents are mentioned as being gone where he can never talk to them again.

entities.name: voldemort's wand
entities.description: The wand of the antagonist Voldemort.

entities.name: harry's wand
entities.description: Harry's wand is mentioned as acting independently and having a connection with Voldemort's wand.

relationships.description: Dumbledore would have believed Harry's story. This is described in the text as 'he knew it'.
Dumbledore explained the connection between Harry's wand and Voldemort's wand to Harry.
Harry's wand is connected with Voldemort's wand. This is described in the text as 'the strange connection that existed between his wand and Voldemort's'.

Harry missed Dumbledore, who is gone where he can never talk to him again. This is described in the text as 'But Dumbledore, like Mad-Eye, like Sirius, like his parents, like his poor owl, all were gone'.

Harry missed Mad-Eye, who is gone where he can never talk to him again. This is described in the text as 'But Dumbledore, like Mad-Eye, like Sirius, like his parents, like his poor owl, all were gone'.

Harry missed Sirius, who is gone where he can never talk to him again. This is described in the text as 'But Dumbledore, like Mad-Eye, like Sirius, like his parents, like his poor owl, all were gone'.
Harry and Voldemort are opponents. This is implied by the context of the story.
